user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_SocketSendTo:
```c
int32 OS_SocketSendTo(osal_id_t sock_id, const void *buffer, size_t buflen, const OS_SockAddr_t *RemoteAddr)
{
    OS_stream_internal_record_t *stream;
    OS_object_token_t            token;
    int32                        return_code;

    /* Check Parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(buffer);
    OS_CHECK_SIZE(buflen);
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(RemoteAddr);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_REFCOUNT, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sock_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        stream = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_stream_table, token);

        if (stream->socket_type != OS_SocketType_DATAGRAM)
        {
            return_code = OS_ERR_INCORRECT_OBJ_TYPE;
        }
        else
        {
            return_code = OS_SocketSendTo_Impl(&token, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr);
        }

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_SocketSendTo:
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_SIZE(val) ARGCHECK((val)>0&&(val)<(UINT32_MAX/2),OS_ERR_INVALID_SIZE)
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct
{
    size_t            ActualLength; /**< @brief Length of the actual address data */
    OS_SockAddrData_t AddrData;     /**< @brief Abstract Address data */
} OS_SockAddr_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I reviewed the function body and related macros/typedefs. There are no statements that assign to or modify any of the function parameters (sock_id, buffer, buflen, RemoteAddr). The checks use macros (OS_CHECK_POINTER, OS_CHECK_SIZE) that evaluate their arguments but, as presented, do not assign to them. All subsequent calls either pass parameters by value (sock_id) or pass pointers to local objects (&token); none pass the address of a function parameter nor perform assignments such as sock_id = ..., buffer = ..., buflen = ..., or RemoteAddr = .... Therefore there are no fragments in this function that appear to violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 (a function parameter should not be modified). If additional macro definitions (e.g. BUGCHECK, ARGCHECK) or the implementations of called functions (OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_SocketSendTo_Impl, OS_ObjectIdRelease) contain hidden assignments to parameter variables, those definitions would need to be reviewed, but based on the provided code fragments there are no suspicious modifications of parameters.
